message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Metamorphic testing and testing with special values
Paper Abstract: The problem of testing programs without test oracles is well known. A commonly used approach is to use special values in testing but this is often insufficient to ensure program correctness. This paper demonstrates the use of metamorphic testing to uncover faults in programs, which could not be detected by special test values. Metamorphic testing can be used as a complementary test method to special value testing. In this paper, the sine function and a search function are used as examples to demonstrate the usefulness of metamorphic testing. This paper also examines metamorphic relationships and the extent of their usefulness in program testing.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "sine function mathematics":

## Definition and Overview

In mathematics, the sine is a trigonometric function of an angle.(no content)The sine of an acute angle is defined in the context of a right triangle: for the specified angle, it is the ratio of the length of the side that is opposite that angle, to the length of the longest side of the triangle (the hypotenuse).

## Extended Definitions

More generally, the definition of sine (and other trigonometric functions) can be extended to any real value in terms of the length of a certain line segment in a unit circle.(no content)More modern definitions express the sine as an infinite series, or as the solution of certain differential equations, allowing their extension to arbitrary positive and negative values and even to complex numbers.

## Applications

The sine function is commonly used to model periodic phenomena such as sound and light waves, the position and velocity of harmonic oscillators, sunlight intensity and day length, and average temperature variations throughout the year.

Web search results for query: "metamorphic testing"

Links: [{"title":"Metamorphic testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metamorphic_testing"},{"title":"Software testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_testing"},{"title":"Test oracle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_oracle"},{"title":"Talk:Metamorphic testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Metamorphic_testing"},{"title":"Metamorphic (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metamorphic_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Metamorphism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prograde_metamorphism"},{"title":"List of mineral tests - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mineral_tests"},{"title":"Metamorphic facies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metamorphic_facies"},{"title":"Shock metamorphism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shock_metamorphism"},{"title":"Schist - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schist"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about metamorphic testing:

## Definition

Metamorphic testing (MT) is a property-based software testing technique, which can be an effective approach for addressing the test oracle problem and test case generation problem.

## The Test Oracle Problem

The test oracle problem is the difficulty of determining the expected outcomes of selected test cases or to determine whether the actual outputs agree with the expected outcomes. To illustrate this challenge, when testing a booking website, a web search for accommodation in Sydney, Australia, returns 1,671 results; are the results of this search correct and complete? This is a test oracle problem. Based on a metamorphic relation, we may filter the price range or star rating and apply the search again; it should return a subset of the previous results.

## How It Works

Rather than trying to determine the absolute correctness of outputs, metamorphic testing exploits properties, called metamorphic relations, across multiple executions of the system.

## History and Applications

Metamorphic testing was invented by T.Y. Chen in a technical report in 1998.(no content)Since then, more than 750 papers have been published by international researchers and practitioners, working further on the theory and practice of MT in real-life applications. Some examples include web services, computer graphics, embedded systems, simulation and modeling, machine learning, decision support, bioinformatics, components, numerical analysis, compilers, and even quantum computing.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"A* search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A*_search_algorithm"},{"title":"Search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_algorithm"},{"title":"Boyer–Moore string-search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boyer–Moore_string-search_algorithm"},{"title":"Binary search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_search_algorithm"},{"title":"Category:Search algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Search_algorithms"},{"title":"Reverse-search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse-search_algorithm"},{"title":"Talk:Search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Search_algorithm"},{"title":"Category:Internet search algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Internet_search_algorithms"},{"title":"Random search - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_search"},{"title":"Reverse image search - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse_image_search"}]

## Search Algorithm Overview

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about search algorithms:

### Definition and Purpose

In computer science, a search algorithm is an algorithm designed to solve a search problem. Search algorithms work to retrieve information stored within particular data structure, or calculated in the search space of a problem domain, with either discrete or continuous values.

### Major Types of Search Algorithms

**List Search Algorithms:**
- Binary, or half-interval, searches repeatedly target the center of the search structure and divide the search space in half.(no content)Binary search is a search algorithm that finds the position of a target value within a sorted array.
- Comparison search algorithms improve on linear searching by successively eliminating records based on comparisons of the keys until the target record is found, and can be applied on data structures with a defined order.

**String Search Algorithms:**
The Boyer–Moore string-search algorithm is an efficient string-searching algorithm that is the standard benchmark for practical string-search literature. It was developed by Robert S. Boyer and J Strother Moore in 1977.

**Pathfinding Algorithms:**
Peter Hart, Nils Nilsson and Bertram Raphael of Stanford Research Institute first published the A* algorithm in 1968. A* achieves better performance by using heuristics to guide its search.

**Tree Search Algorithms:**
Tree search algorithms view the elements as vertices of a tree, and traverse that tree in some special order. Examples of the latter include the exhaustive methods such as depth-first search and breadth-first search, as well as various heuristic-based search tree pruning methods such as backtracking and branch and bound.

I've completed a web search on "software testing" and found comprehensive information from multiple sources. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Software testing is the act of checking whether software meets its intended objectives and satisfies expectations.(no content)Software testing can provide objective, independent information about the quality of software and the risk of its failure to a user or sponsor or any other stakeholder.

## Testing Approaches

Software testing is often dynamic in nature; running the software to verify actual output matches expected. It can also be static in nature; reviewing code and its associated documentation.(no content)Software testing methods are traditionally divided into white- and black-box testing. These two approaches are used to describe the point of view that a test engineer takes when designing test cases. White-box testing (also known as clear box testing, glass box testing, transparent box testing and structural testing, by seeing the source code) tests internal structures or workings of a program, as opposed to the functionality exposed to the end-user.

## Testing Levels

Links: [{"title":"Test oracle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_oracle"},{"title":"Oracle Application Testing Suite - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oracle_Application_Testing_Suite"},{"title":"Metamorphic testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metamorphic_testing"},{"title":"Oracle Real Application Testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oracle_Real_Application_Testing"},{"title":"Software testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beta_Testing"},{"title":"Fuzzing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzing"},{"title":"Software testing controversies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_testing_controversies"},{"title":"Category:Software testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Software_testing"},{"title":"Oracle Database - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oracle_Database"},{"title":"Category:Software testing tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Software_testing_tools"}]

Here are the search results for "test oracle software testing":

## Test Oracle in Software Testing

In software testing, a test oracle is a provider of information that describes correct output based on the input of a test case.(no content)Testing with an oracle involves comparing actual results of the system under test (SUT) with the expected results as provided by the oracle.

### Types of Test Oracles

The search results identify several categories of test oracles:

- **Specified Oracle**: A specified oracle is typically associated with formalized approaches to software modeling and software code construction, connected to formal specification, model-based design, state transition specification, and design by contract.

- **Derived Oracle**: A derived test oracle differentiates correct and incorrect behavior by using information derived from artifacts of the system, including documentation, system execution results and characteristics of versions of the SUT.

- **Human Oracle**: A human can act as a test oracle, and this approach can be categorized as quantitative or qualitative.

### Common Sources for Test Oracles

Test oracles are most commonly based on specifications and documentation.(no content)Examples of oracles include: specifications, contracts, comparable products, past versions of the same product, inferences about intended or expected purpose, user or customer expectations, relevant standards, applicable laws.

### Oracle Products

The results also reference Oracle Application Testing Suite, a comprehensive, integrated testing solution for Web applications, Web Services, packaged Oracle Applications and Oracle Databases.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
